title: [Poll] Which kind of team mate do you prefer?
body:
Basically a spin off of [this](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/q7VdFVxB-do-you-honor-toxic-players-that-play-well-im-curious-as-to-what-everyones-stance-is-on-this) thread.

I wanted to know if people preferred a good team mate that's toxic or a feeding nice guy. I got the impression that more people preferred the latter. I think a poll would give a more clear answer about the number of people in each camp.

replies.body:
neither? 

why cant a nice guy be a good player?
There's no point in including an option for a good player that's well mannered because such a player would be universally preferred. Don't need a poll to know that.

see every one cries about "feeders" well sometimes the enemy is just better. 

there is a difference in INTING /RUNNING IT DOWN then being out played. 

and as far as "feeders" we have all been that person more then once, a bad game, a bad match up, getting camped etc. that dont mean that person is intentionally losing the game. 

you cant expect every one every game to be better then who they are facing. or to play perfectly. there is soo many variables to match ups, runes/keystone, power spike etc. so many difference gaps in 'skill' as well. 

you can have a team of 5 vs a team of 5 with all the same MMR/RANK and there still is gaps in skill with in the same mmr/ranks.
Because people believe those players don't exist.

But if a player's goal is simply to climb (like OP for example), he would probably take a toxic carry over a nice, but incompetent guy. Especially if you experienced all kinds of dumb BS in ranked.

But for players that're not interested in a serious climb (4fun/casual players), they might choose a 2nd option. If youre that kind of a player thats fine, but put yourself in OP's shoes and you'll realise why posts like these are being made and why some people would choose a toxic carry.

> [{quoted}](name=iMidg3t,realm=EUW,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=A57k6jHE,comment-id=00010002,timestamp=2019-12-15T14:10:23.965+0000)

This isn't catered to anyone specifically. My thread is aimed at answering a simple question. How important is winning to the average player?

I primarily play ranked and I love winning games. It's my primary goal. I want to win so much that I will gladly take abuses from my team mates as long as they are playing good. I will gladly take free wins if someone on the enemy team goes afk, is trolling or running it down. Winning and watching my LP go up is what makes this fun for me.

It's a trap question designed to prove your point rather than get an accurate answer. People always prefer a toxic carry over someone you can't carry.

The problem is that you're not forced to be *either*. You're assuming a dichotomy where there is none, by stating the question like you can only be one *or* the other.

Based on your other thread, you're also *going* to try to use this to "prove" that toxicity isn't a problem and Riot shouldn't ban for it, when that's just nonsense, since Riot can and *does* punish for both toxicity and inting.

And, sure, you didn't specify inting. So if we go with toxicity versus inting, a bad player who wants to improve will, over time, actually improve. A toxic person *will not stop being toxic* without any actual incentive to do so.

Y'know what? I'll bite. If we were in some fantastical scenario where there were only the two options available to me, I would choose the amicable player who plays poorly over the toxic jerk who performs well.

Both players are technical liabilities, but the poor performer is the better of two evils. They're more likely to stick with the group, follow advice, and play with the team, whereas the toxic player is more liable to make the game about themselves, turning a 5v5 into a 4v6. They'd think themselves right all the time, they'd try to lone-wolf the game and make picks, and it wouldn't go anywhere well from there.

Can they 1v5 the entire enemy team as Yasuo? Probably. But does that mean they're going to be able to work with their own team and actually do the stuff that's important to win? No.

Functionally, there's no difference between a toxic player who plays well and a toxic player who plays poorly. Both screw over their teams, one way or another.

I have the same conclusion at the end, honestly. After my original comment, that is.

With the person who's just bad, but is willing to cooperate, you have a better chance. Someone who's bad but will cooperate will win more because it's best to work together on a bad call than to make different calls that don't work together.

As a wise man once said: "Apes apart weak, apes together strong".

I would always take the unskilled player who listens over someone who is toxic. The toxic player will get super fed and then blame his teammates when he dies 1v3 and gets a kill. I've been able to carry 4 players who all got beat in lane badly but were willing to coordinate and work together. The toxic player would likely tilt his teammates and make it so they are less likely to listen and work together. It's much more difficult to carry a divided team than it is to carry a united one.

I find your answer very interesting so lets raise the stakes. It will give me some insight into your reasoning. 

You entered a competition where the prize is 100,000 dollars. You are the team captain with sole power to draft whoever you want. Now your pool of choices run the gamut of really chill guys who are less skilled to really skilled hyper antagonistic super competitive players. All the players fall somewhere within these two extremes. During the drafting phase you and the other captain are left to fill the last spot on your respective teams. 

Among the remaining players is a very well known and highly skilled individual. Someone who many people believe will sweep the competition and utterly crush his opponents due to how excessively skilled he is in comparison to everyone else. The problem is that he is known to be very antagonistic in game. He always tries his very best to win but has a tendency to fly off the handle and hurl abuses at his team mates when things don't go well. 

Your other choice is a super chill guy who everyone loves. He is very willing to co-operate, takes criticism well. Makes everyone laugh. He is just loved. But he is known for not being very consistent and is generally not considered that good a player. He knows how to play, sure but he is known for losing his lane in 90% of his games. He tends to always be the first to lose his tower. He tends to always leave lane with a score like 0-7. He's doesn't play the macro game too well. He's never where he is supposed to be and his team often loses objectives because of it. Occasionally though, he will do super well and hard carry a game or two but it's always rare sight. And he is also known for very occasional feats of sheer brilliance where he will pull of dazzling game changing outplays, this being the main reason why he is even allowed to compete. He has a lot of potential but is woefully inconsistent in his performances. 

Now, if it were me, I want the highly skilled player. I don't care if he tells me to off myself every 5 minutes after the game starts. I want to win and he is the best chance at me winning. I'm not trying to be his friend or anything but I will move heaven and Earth to get them him on my team. We can part ways amicable after. I'm curious, how would you fill your remaining spot.

I'd take the chill player, obviously. As stated before, the toxic player, no matter how skilled they are, is inevitably going to be a liability because they won't care what color the health bar is - they'll fight anyone and everyone. The toxic player will damage his team's morale and there'll come that point in the late game when the enemy team isn't playing at their best - because they've been held back from a win for so long and because their "star player" is lashing out at them left and right for the smallest mistakes.

Even if the chill player's _individual_ performance is a gamble, they're not the only player on the team. They've got four other players who can rein them in and keep him from making mistakes, and team play will virtually _always_ be better than individual skill. Plus, the chill player is more likely to help his teammates keep a level head, which'll prevent them from losing it in the late game which would ultimately decide the match.

And besides, it's easy to take a win off of a toxic "pro" who keeps trying to lone-wolf things. "Win lane, lose game" is a saying, after all, and it works the same inversely - "lose lane, win game".

I have to say. I'm honestly surprised you'd make that choice with a 100,000 dollars on the line. Well you're a better man than me. I simply cannot take such chances with that much money on the line.

Also, did you take into account that the famous skilled player still wins a lot of his games. Remember I said, everyone favors him, and by extension, whichever team he is on to sweep the competition. Sure, he might destroy team morale with his behavior but owing to his raw skill he is generally expected to win more often than not.

Dude, I wouldn't care if the toxic pro in this hypothetical scenario was Faker himself. A player with an immense amount of solitary skill but zero team cohesion can still ultimately lose a match in a team game.

If we were hedging bets on a 1v1, sure, I'd probably put money on him, but we're talking about a tournament in a team game. I'm going to want my team to be able to either A. have _all_ players win by playing at their best, or B. lose humbly knowing that they gave their all.

Fame and skill don't mean jack if your team stops wanting to play with you halfway through the match.

Works well with his team mates, even as he's spamming chat about how much they suck and they're doing everything wrong.  Look at Tyler1.  Toxic enough that he got IP banned.  Still knows how to work with others and wins games.  Part of being a skilled player is knowing how to work with others.  Claiming that a skilled player magically forgets how to play the game late game is disingenuous.

I'd take either one over a really nice iron 4 player.  I mean, yea, the person's really nice and all, but I can actually learn stuff from IWD and T1, and personally, I'd have a lot more fun listening to them rant then I would dealing with that poor kid that ran up and got slaughtered for the 33rd time because he didn't know any better (exceptions made if it's a friend of mine that I'm introducing to the game.  In that case I'm playing on a smurf account anyways, and we're having fun talking while I'm explaining stuff to him/her.).

Tyler1 didn't get IP banned (Riot doesn't do those), he got ID banned (ban on sight), there's a difference. Also if you're gonna bring pro players into the topic then you have to mention Dardoch. He's a skilled player for sure but he also has a reputation for being difficult to work with behavior wise and has bounced from team to team because of it, currently being on TSM. You are right in that being a skilled player means knowing how to work with others but it also means not flipping out and flaming people whenever they mess up (constructive criticism is fine, destructive criticism isn't). Being skilled at the game is important, but so is having a good attitude. If you develop a reputation for having an attitude problem then it becomes that much harder to find teams willing to play with you compared to those who are both skilled at the game and don't have behavioral issues.

we did this post time and time again. almost every HONEST person chose the toxic one. because you can mute. but as we all know u cant mute a feeder.

A toxic person will basically never improve without being punished, while someone who's feeding (but not trolling) will get better eventually once they get sick of being low elo.

I have no problem with someone who's just bad at the game but is willing to cooperate. You can plan and adapt around someone just being bad. You can shotcall and help them out. Someone who's being a jackass is going to drag the *entire* team down with them and will never cooperate.
That's interesting because in the other thread I got the sense that almost everyone prefers a well manned feeder over an abusive shithead that's carrying their heavy asses.

False dilemma.

Even if you prefer one over the other the two traits are separate, the decision of what trait is punishable is not determined by your preference of one over the other, nor do you actually get a choice between the two.

Skill in the game and civility are two different traits. You don't trade one for the other. You can't pull aside a civil player who's playing poorly and request that they instead behave like an asshole while playing like challenger.

Playing poorly is also something that a player can't conscientiously change on a dime and it's 100% un-punishable beyond the punishment of losing. Acting like an asshole is malicious and completely within the control of the player, always.

Feeding is not something that is, or should, be punished. The conscious choice to be a dick and attempt to ruin someone else's game is, and should be, punishable.
[I already addressed a similar point.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/A57k6jHE-poll-which-kind-of-team-mate-do-you-prefer?comment=00040000)

That doesn't address 2/3's of my point. The only point that addresses is the observation that skill in the game and civility are two different traits. And all you did was confirm the false dilemma by acknowledging the other possible choices based on those two traits.

You don't address the fact that one is malicious behavior and the other is not, which is what makes one negative quality punishable and the other not. Nor do you address the fact that you're never actually choosing between the two.

You can't pull aside a player playing poorly, tell them to just play better, and **expect them to magically play better**. If it were as simple as choosing to play better, why isn't everyone in challenger?

Being a jerk to someone is completely a choice.
I want to win, but after the match? I feel a lot better playing with nice people instead, win or lose.

Feeders are just a different type of toxicity. But lets just assume they're just having a really rough game and they're not intentionally feeding (it happens). I'll take that player over the toxic person. This is just a game to me. This isn't my job, whatever the results are, it won't really impact my life. If that nice person made the game feel fun, that is what I want in my games. Accept my friend request. 
If you're really talking about actual intentionally feeding, I don't think they're a nice guy. 
I don't really care about toxicity that much. I can just mute them. But I mean, I just like players that make chat fun. I friend players that make the game fun, not players that did well.

Thats perfectly fine. But imo, this game is really fun, win or lose. I take small victories, during laning phase, cs leads, farming well, outplaying someone, working with a team, etc. I play the game because I find it fun, otherwise I have plenty of other games I can play. Even if I lose hard, I can always watch my replay and learn from it. I can think about ways I can improve, what I could do to counteract that specific situation, what I could build instead, etc. I focus more on my own play than my teammates, tho this is a team game so I do want us to help each other. Because of that, I don't understand what people mean by "wasting time". I don't ever really feel like I'm wasting time (or at least, not any more than playing any other fun games, because playing games or watching TV is technically just "wasting time"). I'm not like a saint or anything, I do get frustrated playing sometimes (I won't be toxic to my teammates), but the fun of the game overwhelms my frustrations.
